review_detailed_main: While this tries to be a psychological thriller 'deadly illusions' is a snooze. The acting doesn't feel authentic and there's no chemistry. The storyline is fairly predictable and the brilliant twist falls flat. Characters lacked depth and made it hard to connect to the story. Story was basic and lacked development.

Mary Morrison is a bestselling author who writes novels about "passion, sex, lies, betrayal." In order to focus on writing her next novel, Mary Morrison hires a young, hot nanny to look after her children - and maybe her husband too. It's pretty obvious where this is going. Anna Elizabeth James' 'Deadly Illussions' is a silly, paint-by-numbers, third-rate 'Basic Instinct'-y thriller with its thin and definitely confusing plot. Anyone who can sit through this without cringing at least once deserves an honorary Oscar. Stream it!

review_title: A throwback to 80s made for cable erotic thrillers - but not in a good way.
review_detailed_main:
The one redeeming feature of the 80s erotic thriller genre was that we got to see attractive performers get their kit off and do their thing, albeit in a usually clichéd and highly derivative set up. Sadly, that doesn't happen here. We've got the clichés and the lack of originality but none of the eroticism.

3 stars for the cast for managing to keep straight faces but that's about it.

I mean, the villain CAME OUT FROM NOWHERE. The story of the mother being a writer is almost useless. There was no correlation between the character and the conflict. The motives and background were definitely not in sync with the plot it meant to give.

The acting was not helping either. When they supposed to be happy they didn't look sincere, when someone supposed to be in shock, they didn't even do what people supposed to do when they're shocked.

I personally don't recommend it but go watch it if your day is so good and you need to balance it out by feeling upset a little bit.

The "villain's" goals are unclear and nonsensical. The exposition of what makes the villain the villain is hamfisted and comes out of nowhere. The pieces of the early parts of the movie that is used as "foreshadowing" do not work. And in the end, as always, everything is blamed on a mental illness that the writers (and Hollywood really) don't seem to understand.

I don't recommend watching this.

review_title: If you enjoy classic thrillers, then this movie is for you.
review_detailed_main: Don't listen to the negative reviews. This movie is a thriller and exactly what it says on the tin. If you're expecting it to be something else, then you're wasting your time. Having said that, I enjoyed every bit of it. It was slow paced, character driven, tense and very well made. Yes it's corny and yes it's also trashy in parts too, but that's what makes a thriller a classic. There are some very raunchy parts too, which were not only pleasing to watch, but they added a 'forbidden fruit / Pandora's box' feel to the relationship between Mary and Grace. All of the negative reviews were clearly written by people expecting something completely different to what it actually is. Like I said if you are a fan of thrillers than this movie is for you.
I hope this movie will be Winner of golden raspberries in all categories

review_title: Is it legal for a movie to be this numbingly boring and still be labeled a thriller?

Instead of churning out hideous fare like this, with the hackneyed, cloaked-in-menace "mysterious stranger" at the end, why doesn't Netflix concentrate its resources on a few really good shows? Sure, people come to Netflix for the Coen Brothers or for Better Call Saul and maybe that's how Netflix justifies pumping out drivel like this thing but, on the other hand, I'd be willing to bet that movies like this drive away as many subscribers as Better Call Saul attracts.

If you like movies that keep you thinking WTF, what is going on, who, how, what? repeatedly throughout the movie then this might be for you.

There are elements that still go unanswered, or they might not, it all depends on what you decide is real.

This movie is weird, its unnerving at times, it disturbing at times and it can leave quite an uncomfortable kind of cringe feeling.

Without giving away any of the plot I think people struggle to understand that there is more than one story going on at a time here, its almost like 3 rolled into one, as I said, its really a movie for thinkers. Once you can figure at what those 3 stories are then you may have a better understanding of what is going on in this movie.

Even until the very last 30seconds of the movie, if you have followed it, thought about it, and haven't dismissed it as a boring piece of randomness because your brain switched off an hour ago because of the complexity of the plot, then you should be asking yourself the question... Who, what, why...?

review_detailed_main: I really don't understand what is going on with the people reviewing this movie. It really makes you guess and wonder about things and also makes you go "wth did i just watch?". That does not make it a bad movie... however i do agree with people saying that some of the acting was bad especially Kristin's (Mary). The plot though was quite interesting; personally i think that its either all in Mary's head and both Mary and Grace are her (which is supported by some scenes where Mary does some stuff, for example slushes the bikes' tires, and then we see Grace do the exact same things) or it's the plot of the book sequel she's trying to write because many of the situations in the movie are shown in her board with the book plans. Also, when it shows Grace interviewing for a job, at first she shows off a bad attitude and then the scene replays with Grace's behaviour being the quite opposite indicating that Mary rewrote the scene (if it really is the plot to her book). On the other hand, it could all be real. Thats because if im right and Grace isn't real then how can Elaine and Tom talk about her?anyway the moment where i got confused was the ending. The woman exiting the hospital according to the theories above is either Mary (who could have been in jail -because who the hell leaves the station that easily? Its provably in her head- and afterwards sent to a clinic and found a way to escape), or Grace (who might killed/knicked out Mary and dressed up like her to get out of there) or both in case Grace isn't real and its all in her mind -that also explains why she is in the clinic in the first place-. I know its way too confusing but thats not something negative... i don't get why people are giving it a 1/10 or a 2/10....
I rarely quit a movie, but that was unavoidable with this one. Hardly deserves the description as 'rubbish' - it's an insult the art of movie making. Avoid!

Another day in Lockdown and another film to watch, this time it is Deadly Illusions and here is my review for it. The premise of the film sees an author hire a young babysitter to watch her children, when the two of them start to build a friendship and connection.

Main Character Kristin Davis of Sex and The City fame plays the lead character here and she is just not very good. Her character is really bland and uninteresting with Davis delivering some really cringe worthy dialogue that made her a character that never connected in any way shape or form.

Supporting Characters Greer Grammer plays the young girl that joins as the babysitter and she is also really bad here. She delivers line after line of awful dialogue and she just has some truly bad scenes that makes it hard for you to by anything in the film and the supposed chemistry between her and Davis which is never there. Dermot Mulroney plays Davis' husband in the film and he is literally just phoning it in and just playing the same character he does in every other project he is in. The rest of the cast offer nothing as well and the acting is just really bad.

Story Ever since Fatal Attraction was released, Hollywood has believed they can just churn out similar films for cheap with nothing unique and they are pretty much all bad and this one is no different. This film is laughably bad and throughout it does nothing interesting and then the last act happens and it is is just hilariously ridiculous and makes no sense.

Script The script is terrible, the dialogue is as mentioned above cringe. With drama, humour and romantic dialogue that are all terrible and the actors deliver it in such ways to make it seem even worse. Then someone wrote the ending of the film and they just had no clue what they were doing and maybe they should move into comedy.

Style The style of the film is awful, the pacing is so slow and literally nothing happens for ages and even when it does it is terrible. Plus this film is way too long, a film like this in 2021 should never be 2 hours long and it just keeps on going.

Overall Overall, this is a truly awful film. Deadly Illusions is one of the worst films of the year so far and is one that should never be seen by anybody.

review_title: Oh! I see what they did there
review_detailed_main:
Ok, so this is what happened. The writers had three ideas for an mediocre movie. There is the erotic storyline, where the babysitter seduces both the mother and the father which leads to jealousy. The second storyline is a Fight Club ripoff where the mother develops a side personality, the babysitter, because of stress and surpressed emotions. Third is just a story where they hire a babysitter who turns out to be nuts, maybe making it a murder mystery / slasher movie

Instead of picking one storyline they decided to combine them all, because what could go wrong? The end result is an utter mess and one of the most frustrating movies I've ever seen. The plot and storytelling make absolutely no sense. Acting is weak but there is no one who could have saved this script. Just terrible all around.

Though they're a successful husband and wife team, Dermot manages to lose half their savings. Kristen is then forced to return to work as an author and write a novel in which she's being paid a hefty advance. With two young children distracting Kristen from her work, she decides to hire a nanny and this is where I'll leave the story as to not give anything away. Is this story real? Is it all just part of a book? Is the nanny real? Is the nanny crazy? Is Kristen crazy or is her husband out to get her? There are a lot of ways this film could have gone. Ultimately, it's an OK thriller similar to those 90's thrillers like Basic Instinct, Sliver, etc. Not great, though certainly not bad. A middle of the road effort.

Psychological thrillers usually keep you at the edge of your seat. This movie does manage a decent plot but the treatment is flawed. A writer suffering from a writer's block and maybe deadly illusions.The performances are decent but when you sit back and join the dots it gets too confusing. They should have focused on one person having a mental illness or someone simply being a villain. They instead choose to tease and titillate you in the first half and do too many things in the second half and the end result is an average thriller with an ambiguous ending.

A best seller authoress hires a nanny whilst she attempts to complete her next book.

The mental stress and strain of writing the novel takes its' toil on the writer and causes her to suffer illusion or delusion when trying to finish the book.

Or maybe she is actually experiencing the truthfulness of her life and her desires whilst at he same time her husband and the nanny are living out their feelings, sane or otherwise too?

I loved this film and it had me mostly engrossed throughout.

The poor reviews maybe down to the fact than many viewers cannot accept certain kinds of love, in particular within same sex relationships. That relationship was done brilliantly in the movie.

The two female leads vie with each other to steal the show; both are the winners!

The ending is mightily thought provoking and shocking but at the same time wholly understandable.

8/10.

I watched this with my wife. A story is about a best-selling author, Mary who does not want to write another story as there's a tendency that she needs to have an influence on the current situation (I assumed a dark story) to have a good book. She ended up writing again on the grounds that the monetary offer was good, she got influenced by others to write a follow-up novel, and their financial situation was not that good for her to just be at home with the family. For her to continue, someone has to help look after her juvenile twins while she pens another story. Grace, the baby sitter entered the picture. As the story developed, we wanted to find out what the ending looked like. It ends up that more thinking needs to be done. I will not say that this is a bad film because it gives me and my wife time to discuss what happened. If wether the scene is real or just Mary's imagination on what's going on. There are no conclusions about who among Grace and Mary wore the killer outfit on two scenes . Maybe others can find out themselves. I can still recommend this film if anyone wants to watch a psychological thriller.

Where Kristin Davies' role as a hysterical uptight flower pattern wearing rich housewife is very funny in SatC, it was just plain agony in this god awful flick. Furthermore, the storyline is a mess, the characters are completely unbelievable and the 'erotic' scenes were just cringe as f. As you come towards the end of the movie you just start wondering if the whole production team was on acid or something because it just loses all grip to reality.

I wish their was a law against movies like this. Or at least a way to get compensated for hours lost.

If you value your precious time, skip this disaster and go do something worthwhile.

Deadly Illusions sets off to a promising start before sliding gradually into farce. It feels as if those involved just went along with the flow, perhaps too naive or too scared of the director to speak up about the bizarre script and poor editing. Inconsistent pacing, curious but incomplete interludes and the laughable plot, combined with unconvincing acting and a pathetically weak ending, result in an altogether unsatisfactory performance. If this was produced as a showcase or proposal for a film to be made by a major studio, it would not have sold without significant improvements. As it is, it falls almost completely flat. The one bright spot (sufficient for a second star) is Greer Grammer's vindictive persona that finally emerges after far too much of her vacant sicophantic drivel in the first three-quarters. That at least was convincing and heart-felt, whereas the rest were merely coasting along.

review_title: How did this get the green light?
review_detailed_main: Really, really terrible film. It was almost as if someone said "Let's take Ozon's 'Swimming Pool', a nice dramatic thriller about a writer's creative process, and throw in a little 'Hand That Rock's the Cradle' jazz, and maybe...just maybe...we can come up with something that'll squeak by!" It doesn't squeak by. The end product is abysmal. The writing is lazy and uninspired. For one, Dermot Mulroney's character is an underdeveloped and two-dimensional place-holder in the "insert male here" slot. The directing, editing, acting...all very sub-par. It amazes me that with viewing audiences being as sophisticated as they are today, this product can be heralded as "No.1 in the U. S." on Netflix! Please don't watch this film. Look up "Swimming Pool" instead. If I can save even one person, I'll have done my job.

I can't believe I had set a reminder for this film on Netflix. The "plot" is such a patch-up job with giant holes. It begins with the premise that Kristin Davis is a successful author who hasn't written a new book in a long time not just due to writer's block but also because she somehow "changes" when she writes. So are we supposed to believe that she's imagining the events that follow? That would make more sense than accepting the preposterous behavior of the characters. Then in the climax everything is retrofitted to try to justify the ludicrous preceding 90 minutes but still doesn't make sense. Also did Kristin Davis chip a tooth? She has a terrible lisp throughout, probably exaggerated by the poor sound quality.
How did nobody stop Kristin Davis when she was filming the first scene and just said: please stop. Please. Go home. Please, this is terrible.
Camera work was captivating, I was illusioned into watching this incompetence of a Script writer.

Not y'all thinking movies are supposed to have a clear ending or at least a couple possible outcomes *crying emoji* Hear me out, this movie has amazing cinematography and good acting but in regards to the plot, it obviously was meant exclusively for YOUR interpretation. An absolute embarrassment, and hopefully a career nadir for all involved.

review_title: Probably the worst movie I've ever seen
review_detailed_main: If you're going to watch this movie look at it from the perspective of how a movie can go so wrong.

Mary Morrison (Kristin Davis) is the successful author of a pulp thriller series. She's presently retired to be a homebody with her two young kids and husband. Her publisher is desperate for a new book from her and offers her a $2 million advance. Her husband Tom (Dermot Mulroney) pushes her to take the money after making a bad business deal. She hires Grace (Greer Grammer) from a high-end nanny service. She starts having erotic dreams about the nubile hire.

This is one of those movies that used to be a mid-level theatrical release. It's a bit trashy. It has a few name actors. There is no room for these anymore. It's not good enough to be wanted by anybody. It's getting thrown into the streaming VOD vortex and be lost forever. It tries to be a bit of erotic trash, but it's not. There are no thrills except for an action scene after two hours. It has some potential drama with the cops which is quickly thrown away. These actors are not drawing anybody to this film. This is falling into the mid-level nothingness in today's cinema.

review_title: Absolute masterpiece with best the best twists and acting...ever!

review_detailed_main: Don't waste your time with this not worth it. And you'll want to get your time back.

I'm really in no position to review this movie, as I still haven't seen the last 15 minutes. But, if that doesn't tell you all you need to know, then you need educating about film reviews... For now, I'm going to assume the ending is predictable and lame. The first 1 hour and 45 minutes is, so I don't see why that would suddenly change. In summary it's essentially a modern day remake of The Hand That Rocks The Cradle, an early 90's film that was good for its time. They've altered some aspects to modernise it, like make the live-in babysitters obsession with the mother become sexual, in addition to it being sexual with the husband. But otherwise it wanders no further from the hackneyed plot of "obsessed outsider infiltrates and ruins family". It's one of those films that I think people in the industry still think they're right when they have meetings around tables and say things to each other like "We're gonna show people how wealthy this family is because people love seeing opulence!" When in actual fact that approach is dated and considered very unrelatable these days. It kind of attempts to make you wonder whether the main female character or the babysitter character is the one causing the problems. But it just comes across as muddled and unclear. You get what might be flashbacks, might be memories, or visions from the main character of both herself and the babysitter doing terrible things, because apparently she "gets very dark" when she's writing... yawn. She gets so dark she randomly goes completely mental, dropping the f-bomb at the dining room table in front of her kids, after no hint whatsoever that she was about to lose the plot. And everyone reacts... as if it's fairly normal. Sadly this film suffers far too much from those annoying experiences viewers have, such as saying to him/herself "You wouldn't do that / say that." Or "Why did she do / say that?" many times throughout the film. Ultimately, it bears little resemblance to normal people and normal everyday life, which is a shame because it's a straight up drama based on earth in 2021...

Deadly Illusions review :

First things first. The only reason I spent two hours of my life on this loophole laden and at times, utterly predictable erotic thriller was only for my fave 'Sex and The City' star Kristin Davis. She plays a middle age novelist going through a writers block and to devote more time on work, hires a young nanny (Greer Grammer) to look after the kids. Not long before she starts sexually fantasizing about her sweet new employee and worse, unable to differentiate if this lesbian liaison is indeed her dream or the real world. Intense, eh?!!..you may ask.

Nah, on the contrary, Deadly Illusions is like those typical B movies of Hollywood watched largely for guilt pleasure than anything else. The plot is unreal, the twists are laden with glaring loopholes and the climax (or anti-climax if you could call it that) is a huge let down with some unanswered questions. To put it bluntly, the film just crumbles in the last fifteen minutes. Sad to say this as there was a good concept here which got mauled and killed by inept execution.

As for the ever charming Kristin, her performance is the best of the lot and you will actually sit through this muddle of a movie only if you love her. Others can skip it safely!!

Regards, Sumeet Nadkarni.

IN A NUTSHELL: I was intrigued to watch this movie because I'm an author and author coach. The film's description says: After a bestselling novelist suffering from writer's block hires a new nanny for her children, the line between fiction and reality starts to blur. It's a psychological, erotic thriller that is so badly executed that I'm giving you fair warning here.

THINGS I LIKED: Fans of Sex and the City will be excited to see Kristin Davis starring in a feature film. Unfortunately, she's not a strong enough actress to save this film. Her character is conflicted in many ways. I thought it was sweet that, as a mom, she had different handshakes to say goodbye to each of her kids when she dropped them off at school.

Greer Grammer stars in the movie and also produces it.

I liked the original musical soundtrack by Drum & Lace.

Every author's writing process is different. In the movie, we see Kristen Davis' character writing her book with pen and paper, rather than on a computer. I have some author clients who do that. We also see her create a storyboard on a big board, a technique I recommend to my clients because it really helps you "see" the story develop and allows you to be very intentional where you place certain scenes.

Husbands and wives need to be extremely careful in order to protect their marriage from external relationships and impropriety. For example, my husband NEVER drove home our female babysitters. It wasn't that I didn't trust him or our sweet babysitters. Too many crazy things can happen based on what other people think could have happened, you know? It's just not worth it. No, people shouldn't assume or judge, yet they do.

THINGS I DIDN'T LIKE: Even the title isn't original. So many books have been written with the same name.

I'm surprised that Dermot Mulroney went for this script.

Weird and creepy. I mean who takes a complete stranger bra shopping? That's the first scene when you realize the movie is ridiculous and it just gets worse.

It's often hard to know what's really happening and what's fantasy. Of course, that's the point because the protagonist can't either. Then again, the execution and writing are so bad that it makes you wonder if the writer and director even knew.

There are some really terrible acting moments.

There's a terribly cliched flower moment.

Lots of exposition.

There are twists but they're ridiculous with so many details that don't make sense. We're left with more questions because Act 3 is a complete mess.

There were some "Gollum" moments that made me laugh out loud. (The psycho hobbit in the Lord of the Rings)

TIPS FOR PARENTS: This movie is NOT appropriate for children. Plus, they'll be bored anyway.

You see a married couple rolling around under the sheets. Then later, they do it in a kitchen closet.

You see some skin when two best friends are in a spa sauna & shower.

A pretty girl wears an immodest bathing suit. You see her in a bra many times.

The mom smokes cigars as a symbol of her warped and developing manly obsessions of a young girl.

A woman goes skinny dipping in the pool. Later, you see part of her naked chest in a bathtub.

Tons of inappropriate sexual illusions.

Two women kiss.

You see some blood in a murder scene.

Some profanity, crude language, and an F-bomb You see the naked backside of a man in a shower Violence.

review_title: I don't give anything below a 2 star, unless it's this level of awful
review_detailed_main: I was warned about this. I should have known it was going to be this bad, but I had to be stubborn and watch it myself. If your wondering why I decided to watch it after knowing it was bad. I said in my Thunder Force review that it had a good chance of being my pick for worst movie of the year. While I was writing that I was thinking: "I haven't seen Music or Deadly Illusions, so maybe it's not the worst?" So, I gave one of these a try and immediately regretted it. This is far below a bad movie. This is an awful movie. The story has no clue what it wants to be. The acting is below mediocre. I laughed out loud multiple times about how bad the performances are. The dialog is not good. Its cliché stuff and so on the nose that it hurts. Also, the technical aspects are so annoying. Why are there so many cross-fades? And was the audio doing to this poor actress voice in the end? The only reasons I'm not going below a one star, is because it kept me mildly intrigued. It kept me interested enough to not turn it off. But that third act oh my god. The ending is so badly executed that I wanted to get drunk, so I could forget it as fast as possible. I still have so many questions. It's very hard not to spoil the ending, but why did this person go through all the trouble to get there? There is no reasoning at all. I'm going to watch Ted now just so I can wash away this mess of a movie.

Watched because it was "trending" Didn't expect much but oh my dear lord I didn't think it would be this bad. The whole thing is even more ridiculous than a soap opera. The acting is truly terrible but since the three main characters were able to make it through the most absurd scenes without bursting into laughter, I guess they deserve some credit for that?

There were some interesting concepts floated at the start of this film which could have made it a half decent watch - I'm guessing this is why so many people endured the full run time. For those familiar with the Room, it drew far too many comparisons in terms of bizarre storyline and pointless references as the Tommy Wiseau cult classic, if only it had anywhere near the endearing charm of Tommy or the spoons...

review_title: Seriously, who allowed this to production.
review_detailed_main: I have never written a review concerning a movie but yet here I am, to complain about Netflix top rated 1-10 movies/tv shows that come out, where do they get their information from? This movie was downright boring, slow, and felt like I was putting together the smallest yet most confusing puzzle together. And not an interesting one. This movie barely if at all let who you know the characters which I understand isn't really developed fully in a movie, but this just barely scrapped the surface of anything that would want to keep you engaged. You don't even have to focus on this movie, more like slow background noise where half the movie was kind of silent. This is actually a reason I never got into watching movies, it's 1 1/2 - 3 hours of a forced plot, sometimes okay or even good, but there most the time seems as if writing these plot lines, even the writer would be best to serve his time doing something else. The acting was cringe worthy, awkward, and the part that bothered me the most was when they were having dinner, random scene again, and she told Grace basically I thought you said you didn't intrude on family time, but then Starr's screaming about her husband and Grace sleeping together, but yet the husband sat there as if he were gaslighting her as well. I mean so your telling me a couple who has a good marriage, has a nanny show up and she is sleeping with husband and wife for them to never know. And yet she got the nanny to cook, clean, and watch the kids but yet the nanny is hardly ever with them, she's what, giving massages by the pool or in the bath, and creeping about in a very drifting away movie. I just don't get it. I actually feel pity this movie ever even made it on screen.

First off, why is this so overrated on Netflix?? It was a frustrating experience. While the idea could've been unique had it been executed properly, it was more disappointing and confusing than anything. Also, let's put things in perspective, how is she the number 1, best selling novelist?? Wouldn't everyone know about her if she was? Including the nanny that came over who had no idea who she was (mind you, the young nanny reads novels for fun and they bonded over that) it's a bit of a stretch to make her that successful and renowned, and then we never get to see her write until halfway through the movie. I'm surprised this film has Dermot Mulroney!

The villain's goals are unclear and unmotivated and nonsensical. This couldve been a good psychological thriller but it was just lost about what story it was trying to tell. Also, the bits that were used as foreshadowing pieces we see in the beginning of the movie don't pay off or work later. The fantasy wasnt really fantasy like since it just made no sense (even for fantasy) and in the end, everything is blamed on mental illnesses, of course. But that also means both of them were crazy? The ending was one of those confusing endings were nothing is explained merely because the writer/director doesn't have a clear vision either and just wants you to wonder what the answer could be. I don't recommend this.

Different movie, not a typical mystery or thriller.

The movie first starts a typical mystery/Drama, than gets a bit slow and the momentum of the movie fades a bit, but the last half is filled with a lot of twists and turns.

Overall do think that the film was abit too stretched and there could be some better scenes which could form a better connection between the starting and end of the movie. But the acting from all the actors was good though.

I feel movies like these are interesting that show a different perspective rather than a more predictive storyline so it will be a good watch for people who like unique storylines

An incandescent light bulb, incandescent lamp or incandescent light globe is an electric light with a filament that is heated until it glows. review_title: Good movie, until they throw it all away
review_detailed_main:
Creepy, suspenseful, entertaining and keeps you on your toes. Everything you'd want in a bog-standard, decently watchable psychological thriller - until the last 15 minutes when they gratuitously throw it all out the window in something like a bad parody of the worst M Night Shyamalan movie.

I have never seen a movie go so downhill so quickly in such a poor attempt to deliver a twist ending. What's utterly ridiculous is that up until this point, it does a really good job of hinting at a plot resolution and ending which would have been much, much better.

It's like they switched writers for the last 10 pages of script.
